content.description:
This excellent route is given an "R" rating in several publications, but it seemed well bolted, better so, in fact, than several other climbs here.

Climb excellent pockets and edges past three bolts to a distinct thin crux getting to the fourth bolts. From here, head up and a bit left on positive, 5.9/5.10 terrain to a large ledge. Step a bit left, pull a small roof and climb past another couple of bolts to the anchor.
content.location: On the "lower wall" of the North Side. About 8 feet left, of the obvious roof, following a natural line straight up in a whitish streak of rock. Just left of "Raven Roof Bypass", an odd-looking 5.12a that arcs hard right over the roof before heading back up the wall.

content.description: Well bolted and sustained. The crux is some strenuous pocket pulling with poor feet between bolts two and four. Don't let your guard down too early, however, as an endless sea of 5.10 guards the anchors, including a devious second crux pulling a slight bulge on sharp pockets.
content.protection: 11 bolts (12, if you clip the first bolt of "Nature Hike") to chains
content.location: The third bolted route left of the obvious roof. Just left of "Nature Hike".

content.description: A long fun route with some easier sections and a couple of challenging sections. One can make it harder or easier based on how belly to the bolts you climb.
content.protection: About 12 bolts. Only 1 bolt for anchor but you can place a #1 cam just left of the bolt to back it up. It is easy to retrieve after doing one of the climbs to the left or when you are leaving to catch the tram down.
content.location: 3rd sport route from the left side

content.description:
The classic moderate on the North Side.

The first bolt is fairly high up there, and reaching it may be a bit unnerving for a shaky 5.9 leader. After clipping it, enjoy six more bolts of sustained edging and pocket pulling, with no obvious crux.
content.protection: 7 bolts to chains. It should be possible to top-rope.
content.location: The second bolted route from the left on the North side.

content.description:
This route is not mentioned in any of the guides I found, so feel free to add any relevant info about the route name, rating or FA (edit: thanks for the route name, Rich!). 5.10+ is my best guess at the rating; it felt noticeably harder than the 5.9 to its right, but also a bit easier than the 5.11s lower on the wall.

Cruise up moderate, slabby terrain to some cool jugs at the third bolt. The fourth bolt, which is well-placed over a roof, is attained after a short runout on questionable rock. Figure out how to get your feet over the roof, and crank through some sequential pocket-pulling and crimping to get to the obvious horizontal (crux). A couple more moves, an oddly placed 7th bolt, and an awkward anchor clip finishes off the climb.
content.protection: 7 bolts to chains. It should be possible to get to the anchors from the top, should you be so inclined.
content.location: The farthest left (i.e., farthest uphill) route on the North Side.
